poem:
**The Blame Game**

Crowned coins and weighted words,
weathered economy, numeric decay—
a finger points to fog and rain,
not to gears grinding beneath the fray.
Blame the wind for toppling trees,
as if a breath could break the roots;
we wander in the fiscal forest,
lost, among our tarnished truths.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "It’s the Economy, Stupid! review – engaging account of maths, money and personal cost The title is a phrase coined by a strategist for Bill Clinton’s 1992 presidential campaign amid the recession and its deployment in this show is emphatically ironic. To cite recession as the cause of a broken economy is, according to writer-performer Joe Sellman-Leava, like blaming the weather for causing climate disaster. This becomes self-evident over the course of this dramatised lecture". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
